videoSnippet.title: Calling Mikhail Tal | Gelfand vs Kramnik | Candidates Tournament 2013. | Round 7
videoSnippet.description:
#agadmator In what was the shortest round of the FIDE World Chess Candidates’ Tournament so far, Levon Aronian of Armenia and Magnus Carlsen of Norway maintained their 1.5 point lead over Russians Vladimir Kramnik and Peter Svidler. Against Teimour Radjabov of Azerbaijan, Carlsen needed to sacrifice an exchange to wear off dangerous threats against his king, which proved to be sufficient. Aronian got a small positional advantage against Alexander Grischuk of Russia, who saved himself by going for active defence. For a moment Kramnik was in big trouble, but he escaped with a draw when his opponent Boris Gelfand of Israel refrained from playing actively on move 19. Vassily Ivanchuk of Ukraine and Peter Svidler of Russia played the shortest draw of the round in a Scotch game that quickly turned into an endgame.

Read more here: http://london2013.fide.com/en/component/content/article/1-news-en/206-four-draws-in-round-7-fide-candidates-aronian-a-carlsen-maintain-15-point-lead

Check out all photos from Round 7 of the 2013 candidates tournament here http://london2013.fide.com/images/stories/gallery/Round%207/index.html#

Boris Gelfand vs Vladimir Kramnik
World Championship Candidates (2013), London ENG, rd 7, Mar-23 
Nimzo-Indian Defense: Normal Variation. Gligoric System Exchange at c4 (E54)

1. d4 Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Bb4 4. e3 O-O 5. Bd3 d5 6. Nf3 dc4 7. Bc4 c5 8. O-O cd4 9. ed4 b6 10. Qe2 Bb7 11. Bg5 Nbd7 12. Rac1 Qb8 13. Rfd1 Rc8 14. Bd3 Bd6 15. g3 a6 16. Bf6 Nf6 17. Ne4 Rc1 18. Rc1 Ne8 19. Ned2 Qd8 20. Be4 Rc8 21. Qf1 Rc1 22. Qc1 Qc8 23. Qc3 Nf6 24. Bb7 Qb7 25. Ne5 Nd5 26. Qc6 Qc6 27. Nc6 Kf8 28. Nc4 Bc7 29. Ne3 Ne3 30. fe3 Bd6 31. Ne5 Be5 32. de5 Ke7 33. Kf2 Kd7 34. e4 Kc6 35. Ke3 Kc5 36. Kd3
